Access to articles in regional publications that pertain to a wide range of North Carolina-related topics.
Mrs. Sallie Southall Cotton was one of North Carolina's greatest women. Among her accomplishments were organizing in 1899 the End of the Century Club in Greenville for women to discuss books and sponsor community service projects and being a driving force in founding the North Carolina Federation of Women's Clubs, an organization that enabled women statewide to speak as a group for public school improvement, prison reform, and aid to the poor and elderly.
Description Vol. 3, no. 1 (June 1, 1935);Title from cover.;"A weekly survey of North Carolina.";This item digitized by the North Carolina Digital Heritage Center.
              TORiCAL SOCIETY STATE HIS THE CAMERON SUN AND THE WEEKLY OBSERVER VOLUME XLII CAMERON, CLINTON COUNTY, MISSOURI, MAY 24, 1928 NUMBER 13 Get M. W. C. Diplomas Degrees Conferred on College Classes Tuesday President Cutshall of I Li IT Is Speaker. Closing the 55th year for Missouri Wesleyan College, commencement exercises were held Tuesday afternoon in the First M. E. church and degrees were conferred, by President E. J. Gale. Musical numbers were by the Tracy orchestra, by Miss Eleanor Downey, pianist, who played Gavotte et Musette, and by Prof. Luther Swift, who sang, "Where'er You Walk" and "Life." The commencement speaker was Dr. Elmer Guy Cutshall, president of IlifC School of Theology, Denver. Education itself requires educating, according to Dr. Cutshall, who, in a thoughtful and thought-proving address discussed the province and purposes of education. The direction given to education, according to Dr. Cutshall, Is all important. To that task the religious forces have addressed themselves in establishing colleges such as Missouri Wesleyan. The program of tax-supported education needs the influence of the christian college and the work of these institutions is vital to the perpetuity of our christian standards and ideals. Many former students as well as many relatives and friends of the graduates were here for the exercises. TRUCK INTO A GBATE An accident unprecedented checked the trip of Roy Bridgewater to Nevada Tuesday with a big load of fixtures belonging to the Frisco Market Co. A short distance this side of Platts-fcurg as the truck was rolling along a smooth and dry road one of the rear wheels suddenly dropped down to the axle, instantly stopping the machine.An investigation showed the truck had broken through into an old grave over which thousands of cars and trucks had passed and which perhaps for a hundred years and more had lain unknown beneath the path of travel. Whose they are may never be known. The truck remained with the wheel in the grave over Tuesday night as no means could be devised to raise its heavy weight. It was pulled out yesterday by a 20-horse-power tractor. AVAS ROTARY SPEAKER Dr. Elmer Guy Cutshall, president of Iliff School of Theology, spoke at Rotary luncheon yesterday' on the sixth object of Rotary, which concerns world-wide peace through mutual understanding. Science, he says, has broken down barriers of time and space so rapidly that various races and nations have been unable to readjust themselves to their proximity to one another. Rotary is performing a high service in bringing them to a hasis of understanding, mutual confidence and good will. Dr. Cutshall is a Denver Rotarian. Dean Chas. N. Burrows of Simpson college, Indianola, Iowa, another Rotarian. was also a visitor. The club will meet next Thursday for luncheon instead of on Wednesday, which is Memorial Day. WHAT ABOUT THE CEMETERIES! Approach of Memorial Day reminds us again of the neglected condition of the Cameron cemeteries. Some work has been done on them, some is being done, but a unified program needs to be adopted that will entirely change their appearance, bringing it onto a par with cemeteries in other communities where the resting place of the dead is a beauty spot. The sentiment attaching to this season of the year should be an urge to action. MADE EXAMINATION RECORD Paul T. Fiddick, recently appointed a clerk in the Cameron postofflce, took his first examination Tuesday covering the dispatching of mail. Throwing 900 cards representing the postoffices and junction points in North Missouri Fiddick made 100 per cent. Louis Kaucher, chief ulerk, who came here from St. Joseph to conduct the examination, says it is the first time he has given the examination to a new clerk who made a perfect score. WHITE THE VESPERS SPEAKER Dr. Gay C. White, pastor of the First M. E. church of Urbana, 111., an alumnus of Missouri Wesleyan college, was the vespers speaker at the college Sunday evening. Besides his inspiring address, Dr. White brought many reminiscences of former days. He has had a highly successful career in the ministry and gives much of the credit for his achievements to his Alma Mater. The service, held in front of the liberal arts building, was delightful throughout. NEW FORDOIt FORD IS OUT Production has started on the new Fordor Ford sedans and cars of this type are being turned out from the Kansas City branch. Walter W. Hammer, local dealer, expects early delivery to him of this style of the popular new machines. He will drove home two more Fords Friday. He this week delivered a phaeton and a coupe, making 14 cars being driven now by local customers. ROOMY NEW QUARTERS Sam Bauer has his auto wrecking, auto parts and auto service establishment open in his new and roomy quarters on North Walnut street. He has lots of room and is in better shape than formerly to care for trade. He will open a filling station soon, in connection with his other branches. M. W. C. ANNUAL MEETING Board of TrnMees In Session Tuesday Officers Unchanged for Coming Year. Members of the board of trustees of Missouri Wesleyan college, in annual session in the liberal arts building Tuesday reviewed the work of the past year and made plans for the future, which hdlds more optimistic promise than has been the case in the past. Board members believe the merging of Missouri Wesleyan and Baker University adds strength and standing to the college here and will bring increased enrollment and financial support. Dr. E. J. Gale will continue as president, with Dean D. L. Dalke at the head of the faculty. The entire personnel of the faculty has not been selected, but those who so far have been chosen assure a strong and able teaching force. Officers of the board were re-elected as follows: President, H. F. Lawrence of Cameron; vice president, Rev. Jos. W. Thompson of Bethany; secretary. Rev. Jay J. Cokely of La-throp; treasurer, C. P. Dorsey of Cameron. Other members of the executive committee, A. J. Althouse, Judge Alex Shepherd and F. B. Klepper. Trustees selected include Oscar D. Kochan of Maysville, Rev. J. J. Cokely of Lathrop; Rev. R. L. Henry of St. Joseph and W. R. Clelland of New Hampton. AXM'AL LAWN FETE The lawn fete given at the college last evening by the Aesthesian Society was beautiful and attractive. The scene was a forest with-an enchanted pool and magic carpet. There were fairies, water nymphs and good and evil spirits who were appropriately dressed and who portrayed their parts most appropriately. Solo dances were given by, June Creason, leader of the nymphs, and Opal Miller, leader of the fairies. The fete was sponsored by Miss Herring, who, together with the Aes-thesians, deserves much credit for the splendid entertainment. Miss Stella Crockett furnished piano numbers and Miss Ada Ruth .Alley read the story of the play, which was of her own composition. Between acts a splendid talk was given by Jos. H. Dusenberry. 310 RE TEACHERS ELECTED Prof. Chas. C. Crosswhite, new superintendent of the Cameron schools, met with the board Monday evening and matters pertaining to next year's school term were discussed. Miss Motter of Kirksville was elected sewing instructor, succeeding Miss Hansel. Misses Lucille Campbell and Ruth Alley were selected as teachers in the grades at the Goodrich school. Abe Lucas, James Mallory and W. S. Marquis were re-employed as janitors. Cars Collided. A woman connected with the Federal Prohibition Enforcement department, operating out of Omaha, driving south on highway 69 in a Buick roadster, and Joe Cline, going north, driving a new Ford coupe, collided Sunday afternoon, damaging both cars. The Ford was damaged more than the Buick, a fender and wrheel being torn off. Fortunately, no one was injured.Elected to Honorary Society. Raymond Peck, student at Missouri University, spent Saturday, Sunday and Monday- here with home folks. Raymond has been elected to the Sigma Xi Scientific Honarary Society. A student, to be a member of this society, must have high grades and be of clean character. Cameron friends are glad to learn of Mr. Peck's preferment. Undenvent Operation. Mrs. R. L. Macrae underwent an operation for appendicitis Monday noon at the Independence sanitarium in Independence. At present she is improving nicely. Mr. Macrae went to Independence Sunday and remained for a few days. His brother, Roy, of Holden assisted in the shoeshop during his absence. - Ford Anderson Burned. Experimenting with some powder found in a bottle, Ford Anderson ap- i plied a lighted match and the con tents of the bottle exploded, burning him on the face and one arm, severely, Saturday morning. He was taken to Dr. Bowman, who dressed the wounds. He is getting along nicely although the burns are very painful. . Moving to Cameron. Mr. and Mrs. S. D. Juleson have moved here from Ottawa, Kas., and will occupy the J. W. Perry property on West Fifth street. Mr. Juleson is a traveling man. Delivered Memorial Address. Rev. John Boone drove to Plymouth, Carroll county, Sunday afternoon, where he delivered the annual memorial address for the I. O. O. F. lodge there. Kidder Lady Dies. Mrs. T. J. Anient died at her home in Kidder Tuesday night after a long illness from cancer. Funeral services are being held this afternoon. EW STYLE GLASSES Shown May 26th. Those greasy, corroded, or old style glasses make you look ten years older and brand you as out-of-date, even more than old hats or clothing. Let. Dr. Palm show you the newest frames at Midland ho tel in Cameron next Monday; $3.00 to ?3.00. Adv. (13-lt) Jas. C. Baker A Bishop New Member of Episcopacy Is Son of Former President of Missouri Wesleyan College. Methodists of the world in their general conference at Kansas City yesterday elected as a bishop Dr. James C. Baker, son of the late Dr. B. W. Daker, years ago president of Missouri Wesleyan college in Cameron. He was at that time a student at the college. His preferment will be learn ed of with genuine satisfaction by old friends in this city and throughout the Missouri conference. Dr. Baker was the founder of the Wesley Foundation movement which was established at the University of Illinois to provide religious influence for students in tax supported institutions and is still in charge there. The movement has spread throughout the nation. Five years ago, Dr. Baker was one of the speakers In connection with the installing of Dr. E. F. Buck as president of Missouri Wesleyan college. ALUM XI HOLD BANQUET Joy and sorrow co-mingled Tuesday evening when alumni of Missouri Wesleyan surrounded the banquet tables in Rice Hall for the annual banquet.Happy meeting of graduates of former years was the occasion for happy reminiscences, but the merry company paused in its enjoyment and sadness swept through all hearts as tributes were paid to the memories of Dean H. C. Kelsey and Dr. E. B. Thompson, prominent alumni, who during the past few months had passed suddenly out of this life. President Lester C. Slayton presided, and extended greetings from the alumni to the present graduates. Clarence Byers, class president, responded on behalf of the class. The invocation was by Rev. Jos. W. Thompson of Bethany. President Gale and Dr. L. A. Wilson responded to toasts on the present and future of Wesleyan, and Dr. Stella Dodd of Sononchia, C. P., India, spoke on "A Wesleyanite in India." The charge to the graduating class was given by Prof. Wilson Thomas. Music was furnished by two quartets, one of women and the other of men the singers being Mesdames Lou Gene Evans Woods, Mildred Robison Belcher, Marion Hulsizer Williams and Gladys Frances Hicks; and Messrs. Luther Swift, Charles Groom, Joe Williams and Kenneth Crawford. The attendance and interest were excellent. R. T. Z'S INITIATED Ten new members were iniiiated into the R. T. Z. society, Friday morn ing. The R. T. Z. is a high school society and ten new members are chosen each year. The new members were taken to the Park school where breakfast was cooked. They were then dressed in old-fashioned clothing and taKen to the college chapel. After chapel services, a parade was formed and traversed up and down Third street. Saturday night they were the guests at a line party at the Royal. The new members: Misses Mildred Brown, Ailene Brower, Louise De-Shon, Dorothy Crawford, Virginia Holland, Guenavere Knoch, Mae Morton, Esther Shaw, Elizabeth Whiteaker and Frances Watson. ALPHA PSI OMEGA The Theta cast from Missouri Wes leyan College of the Alpha Psi Ome ga, a national honorary dramatic fra ternity, held a 6 o'clock dinner last evening at the Park Cafe. This has become an annual affair and is eagerly looked forward to by all members of the Grand Cast. The dinner followed the initiation of three Wesleyan students into fellowship of this fraternity: Eileen Kranz, Page Pendleton and Bert Rushton. CHIEF ENGINEER HIS FRIEND Prof. Louis Theilmann was greatly pleased when President Coolidge named Carl W. Sturtevant of New York City as chief engineer for flood control work in the Mississippi val ley. In the first place, Sturtevant is am ply qualified, and in the second he and Prof. Theilmann were classmates in their college days. WiU Leave for Europe. Mrs. G. G. Brown has received word from her son Sidney, in St. Louis that he will leave there Monday from New York, where he will board the ship Maria, for Italy. Sidney will help look after a load of mules which is being shipped from Missouri to Europe. He expects to be gone from six to eight weeks and is anticipating a wonderful trip sight-seeing. Will Teach in Hawaii. William O'Neal, who has been teaching the past winter in Winona, Minn., returned to Cameron Saturday for the summer vacation. Mr. O'Neal was offered the principalship of the Win ona schools for next school term, but did not accept, and will teach in the schools at Honokaa, Hawaii. He will leave for the islands in August. Passed Away. Mrs. Caroline Bell (colored), aged 75, passed away at her home on West Cornhill Tuesday evening after an illness of one day. Mrs. Bell suffered a stroke of paralysis Tuesday morning and died that evening. Driving New Ford. W. C. Sampson is the owner of a new Tudor Ford purchased from Walter W. Hammer, Cameron dealer, delivered Friday. Death As Result Of Fall Ulnier Warner, Roofing Expert, Step-Ieil ltackward fo Death From Goodrich Auditorium Roof. High winds recently whipped part of the roofing off the Goodrich auditorium and the P. Stauffer Rooiing Co. of Mobeiiy, who laid the roof sent, sent a force of workmen here to repair the damage. Wulklng about on the roof superintending the job, Saturday, Elsworth Warner, 47 years old, who was in charge of the work as an expert, stepped backward from the roof. In the fall, he sustained a compound fracture of one leg and a broken arm besides internal injuries. lie was rushed to the Methodist hospital in the Poland ambulance by Dr. L. A. Wilson, who was called to attend him, but his injuries were so severe that death ensued Sunday. WILLI A MS- HEN I) F. R SO N Miss Grace Henderson and Roland Williams were united in marriage Monday afternoon at the home of Rev. H. R. Mills, pastor of the First M. E. church in St. Joseph. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Henderson, for many years prominent citizens of Cameron. She is a graduate of Missouri Wes leyan college of Cameron and the Curry School of Expression at Boston, and has taught expression at the Missouri Christian college in Camden Point, at William Woods college at Fulton and at Missouri Wesleyan col lege, bhe is a young woman of un usual talent and charm and is highly popular possessing a wide circle of friends. The groom is also a member of one of the community's old and esteemed families, being a large land owner and farmer south of Cameron. The happy couple will reside on his farm south of town. The Sun joins their many friends in wishing them a long, prosperous and happy wedded life. M. W. C. RECITAL A splendid recital was given at the College chapel Monday evening by Miss Ruth Pittman, reader; Miss Vera Lou Saxer, pianist, and Miss Eleanor Downey, pianist. A large crowd was present to enjoy the delightful pro gram, which was as follows: Readings, "Rainbow Land" and "Rejected," Miss Pittman, accompanied by Miss Saxer; piano solos, "Arabesque en forme d' Etude," and "The Old Refrain," Miss Saxer; reading, "Molly's Boy," Miss Pittman; piano duets, "Butterfly," "Eastern Intermezzo" and "Gypsy Dance," Misses Downey and Saxer; readings, "Black Blue Grass Widow," and "Imph-m," Miss Pittman; piano solo, "Romance," Vera Lou Saxer; readings, "L'Envoi" and "Mu.4ic on the Rappahauock,," Miss Pittman, accompanied by Miss Downey, vocalist, and Miss Saxer, pianist.Ushers: Misses Irene Moon, Lorraine Shirts, Ada Ruth Alley, Lois Dusenberry, Gertrude Buck and Thel-ma Farris. CITY COUNCIL MEETS The city council met in regular session Monday evening with Mayor J. C. McComb, presiding. The minutes were read and the usual appropriation ordinance passed. The city attorney was directed to prepare an ordinance prohibiting bill boards in the city limits. The meeting adjourned until Friday night "when bids will be received for the graveling of Orange and Prospect streets. TRI BETA BANQUET The Beta Beta Beta Biological fra ternity of Missouri Wesleyan college enjoyed a banquet at the Park Cafe Monday evening. The honor guests were the faculty advisors, Dr. L. A. Wilson and Prof. L. G. Slayton, and the Mesdames Slayton and Wilson. Goldie Boureltn v.: toast master. The idea of the three B's was carried out in the toasts. Prof. Slayton gave a toast on "Biology," David Foster on "Botany," and Dr. Wilson, "Bacteriology." A saxophone solo was given by Cleo Hardin and Miss Hazel Porter gave a vocal solo. This was the closing event of the Beta Beta Beta fraternity for the year. Howser, Jr., the manager, is pre paring for a good business. .Mrs. Ward Worse. C. M. E. hospital in St. Joseph Thursday morning. He is getting along very nicely. Shakespeare Club. OPEN NIGHTS I will be open on Thursday nights until 9:30 p. m. during band concert season. Bring me your poultry, eggs, cream and hides. CAMERON POULTRY CO., jW. H. Davison. (13-lt) T,,K ( 0I Lf:(;K baccalaureate Inspiring Sermon by President Flem. ing of linker UnUersity Heard By Many. An audience which taxed the capacity of Khe . spacious Methodist church attended the annual baccalaureate services for Missouri Wesleyan college Sunday morning. Services at other churches were dismissed for the morning hour and the various congregations united in the exercises. In the processional were the faculty, the graduates and the members of the large chorus choir. In accordance with the custom established throughout many years, the Hallelujah Chorus was rendered by the choir, and was beautifully given. The choir was directed by Hadley Crawford, a student under the late Prof. H. C. Kelsey. President E. J. Gale of Missouri Wesleyan introduced as the speaker, President W. B. Fleming of Baker University. The coming of Dr. Fleming, at the invitation of President Gale and the Senior class, was highly fitting as a merger Is in process between the two institutions and while Missouri Wesleyan will continue to do two years of work here, it will be a part of Baker University, and by the merger, Baker University becomes a part of this community as well as carrying from this time forward the work of the upper two years heretofore at Missouri Wesleyan. Dr. Fleming's sermon was an urge to the discovery of worth while things and his thought was developed with a clearness and eloquence that impressed it upon the hearts and minds of his hearers. So many things we desire are within reach if we but knew how to put forth our hand and take them, Dr. Fleming told the class and his audience. But all too often people hurry here and there in quest for their heart's desire and never find it because they fail to envision the things worthwhile. Supreme among all objects sought by man is the finding of God, Dr. Fleming said. Many miss Him, "Though he be not far from any one of us." To miss God is to miss the supreme good in life; the very essence of life itself. Getting education is desirable; achieving success in professional or business life is desirable, but the finding of God in the heart of an individual ennobles his life", broadens and sweetens it as nothing else can do. Prefacing his sermon, Dr. Fleming took occasion to express cordial feelings for Missouri AVesleyan college and its interests, and toward this community. It is his belief that the new relationship will prove of lasting benefit both to the interests of Missouri Wesleyan college and Baker University, and in the largest degree to the cause of christian education. Dr. Fleming's earnestness, his devotion to the highest and best education for young people and his spirit of friendliness made a most favorable inipressio;i on his many hearers. ANNUAL ARTS CONTEST The annual fine arts contest under direction of the M. W. C. Alumni Association, was held at the college chapel Tuesday evening. The program was presided over by Prof. Lester Slayton, alumni president. A large crowd was present and enjoyed the splendid program. Winners in the contests were as follows: Piano, first Vera Lou Saxer, who played "Romance"; second, Mildred Kelsey, "Prelude in G Minor," and third, Frances Warren, "Jugglery." Voice: First, Harvey Croy, "Down to the Sea in Ships"; second, Wesley Foster, "The Poor Man's Garden," and third, Marjorie Milstead, '"Tis June, My Dear." Expression: First. Muriel Williams, "Shift of Fate"; second, Virginia Mc-Cue, "Aux Italiens," and third, Ada Ruth Alleys "For Dear Old Yale." Purchased New Studebaker. Mr. and Mrs. George Zancker have purchased a new Studebaker Royal Dictator sport model sedan. It is in two shades of tan and has wire wheels, giving it a very attractive appearance. The car is being shipped direct from the factory and will be delivered to the Zanckers the last of the week. Mr. and Mrs. Zancker sold their Pontiac sedan to Mr. and Mrs. C. E. Gerrell of the Edgar Jones players. I. 0. 0. F. BANQUET The I. O. O. F. Imperial Encampment will hold their annual banquet at the Park Cafe Monday night. Byrd of Maysville, agent in this territory for the New York Life Insurance Co., had the notable distinction of standing tenth in point of production in the entire United States in the Spring Round-Up campaign recently closed. He is a tireless worker and a square shooter and is developing a fine business. Mr. Byrd returned the last of the week from a convention of New York Lige agents held in St. Louis. He is getting along very satisfactorily. Miss Louise Ray of Turney was operated on for appendicitis Saturday at Mercy hospital in St. Joseph. She is improving nicely. Transcript TORiCAL SOCIETY STATE HIS THE CAMERON SUN AND THE WEEKLY OBSERVER VOLUME XLII CAMERON, CLINTON COUNTY, MISSOURI, MAY 24, 1928 NUMBER 13 Get M. W. C. Diplomas Degrees Conferred on College Classes Tuesday President Cutshall of I Li IT Is Speaker. Closing the 55th year for Missouri Wesleyan College, commencement exercises were held Tuesday afternoon in the First M. E. church and degrees were conferred, by President E. J. Gale. Musical numbers were by the Tracy orchestra, by Miss Eleanor Downey, pianist, who played Gavotte et Musette, and by Prof. Luther Swift, who sang, "Where'er You Walk" and "Life." The commencement speaker was Dr. Elmer Guy Cutshall, president of IlifC School of Theology, Denver. Education itself requires educating, according to Dr. Cutshall, who, in a thoughtful and thought-proving address discussed the province and purposes of education. The direction given to education, according to Dr. Cutshall, Is all important. To that task the religious forces have addressed themselves in establishing colleges such as Missouri Wesleyan. The program of tax-supported education needs the influence of the christian college and the work of these institutions is vital to the perpetuity of our christian standards and ideals. Many former students as well as many relatives and friends of the graduates were here for the exercises. TRUCK INTO A GBATE An accident unprecedented checked the trip of Roy Bridgewater to Nevada Tuesday with a big load of fixtures belonging to the Frisco Market Co. A short distance this side of Platts-fcurg as the truck was rolling along a smooth and dry road one of the rear wheels suddenly dropped down to the axle, instantly stopping the machine.An investigation showed the truck had broken through into an old grave over which thousands of cars and trucks had passed and which perhaps for a hundred years and more had lain unknown beneath the path of travel. Whose they are may never be known. The truck remained with the wheel in the grave over Tuesday night as no means could be devised to raise its heavy weight. It was pulled out yesterday by a 20-horse-power tractor. AVAS ROTARY SPEAKER Dr. Elmer Guy Cutshall, president of Iliff School of Theology, spoke at Rotary luncheon yesterday' on the sixth object of Rotary, which concerns world-wide peace through mutual understanding. Science, he says, has broken down barriers of time and space so rapidly that various races and nations have been unable to readjust themselves to their proximity to one another. Rotary is performing a high service in bringing them to a hasis of understanding, mutual confidence and good will. Dr. Cutshall is a Denver Rotarian. Dean Chas. N. Burrows of Simpson college, Indianola, Iowa, another Rotarian. was also a visitor. The club will meet next Thursday for luncheon instead of on Wednesday, which is Memorial Day. WHAT ABOUT THE CEMETERIES! Approach of Memorial Day reminds us again of the neglected condition of the Cameron cemeteries. Some work has been done on them, some is being done, but a unified program needs to be adopted that will entirely change their appearance, bringing it onto a par with cemeteries in other communities where the resting place of the dead is a beauty spot. The sentiment attaching to this season of the year should be an urge to action. MADE EXAMINATION RECORD Paul T. Fiddick, recently appointed a clerk in the Cameron postofflce, took his first examination Tuesday covering the dispatching of mail. Throwing 900 cards representing the postoffices and junction points in North Missouri Fiddick made 100 per cent. Louis Kaucher, chief ulerk, who came here from St. Joseph to conduct the examination, says it is the first time he has given the examination to a new clerk who made a perfect score. WHITE THE VESPERS SPEAKER Dr. Gay C. White, pastor of the First M. E. church of Urbana, 111., an alumnus of Missouri Wesleyan college, was the vespers speaker at the college Sunday evening. Besides his inspiring address, Dr. White brought many reminiscences of former days. He has had a highly successful career in the ministry and gives much of the credit for his achievements to his Alma Mater. The service, held in front of the liberal arts building, was delightful throughout. NEW FORDOIt FORD IS OUT Production has started on the new Fordor Ford sedans and cars of this type are being turned out from the Kansas City branch. Walter W. Hammer, local dealer, expects early delivery to him of this style of the popular new machines. He will drove home two more Fords Friday. He this week delivered a phaeton and a coupe, making 14 cars being driven now by local customers. ROOMY NEW QUARTERS Sam Bauer has his auto wrecking, auto parts and auto service establishment open in his new and roomy quarters on North Walnut street. He has lots of room and is in better shape than formerly to care for trade. He will open a filling station soon, in connection with his other branches. M. W. C. ANNUAL MEETING Board of TrnMees In Session Tuesday Officers Unchanged for Coming Year. Members of the board of trustees of Missouri Wesleyan college, in annual session in the liberal arts building Tuesday reviewed the work of the past year and made plans for the future, which hdlds more optimistic promise than has been the case in the past. Board members believe the merging of Missouri Wesleyan and Baker University adds strength and standing to the college here and will bring increased enrollment and financial support. Dr. E. J. Gale will continue as president, with Dean D. L. Dalke at the head of the faculty. The entire personnel of the faculty has not been selected, but those who so far have been chosen assure a strong and able teaching force. Officers of the board were re-elected as follows: President, H. F. Lawrence of Cameron; vice president, Rev. Jos. W. Thompson of Bethany; secretary. Rev. Jay J. Cokely of La-throp; treasurer, C. P. Dorsey of Cameron. Other members of the executive committee, A. J. Althouse, Judge Alex Shepherd and F. B. Klepper. Trustees selected include Oscar D. Kochan of Maysville, Rev. J. J. Cokely of Lathrop; Rev. R. L. Henry of St. Joseph and W. R. Clelland of New Hampton. AXM'AL LAWN FETE The lawn fete given at the college last evening by the Aesthesian Society was beautiful and attractive. The scene was a forest with-an enchanted pool and magic carpet. There were fairies, water nymphs and good and evil spirits who were appropriately dressed and who portrayed their parts most appropriately. Solo dances were given by, June Creason, leader of the nymphs, and Opal Miller, leader of the fairies. The fete was sponsored by Miss Herring, who, together with the Aes-thesians, deserves much credit for the splendid entertainment. Miss Stella Crockett furnished piano numbers and Miss Ada Ruth .Alley read the story of the play, which was of her own composition. Between acts a splendid talk was given by Jos. H. Dusenberry. 310 RE TEACHERS ELECTED Prof. Chas. C. Crosswhite, new superintendent of the Cameron schools, met with the board Monday evening and matters pertaining to next year's school term were discussed. Miss Motter of Kirksville was elected sewing instructor, succeeding Miss Hansel. Misses Lucille Campbell and Ruth Alley were selected as teachers in the grades at the Goodrich school. Abe Lucas, James Mallory and W. S. Marquis were re-employed as janitors. Cars Collided. A woman connected with the Federal Prohibition Enforcement department, operating out of Omaha, driving south on highway 69 in a Buick roadster, and Joe Cline, going north, driving a new Ford coupe, collided Sunday afternoon, damaging both cars. The Ford was damaged more than the Buick, a fender and wrheel being torn off. Fortunately, no one was injured.Elected to Honorary Society. Raymond Peck, student at Missouri University, spent Saturday, Sunday and Monday- here with home folks. Raymond has been elected to the Sigma Xi Scientific Honarary Society. A student, to be a member of this society, must have high grades and be of clean character. Cameron friends are glad to learn of Mr. Peck's preferment. Undenvent Operation. Mrs. R. L. Macrae underwent an operation for appendicitis Monday noon at the Independence sanitarium in Independence. At present she is improving nicely. Mr. Macrae went to Independence Sunday and remained for a few days. His brother, Roy, of Holden assisted in the shoeshop during his absence. - Ford Anderson Burned. Experimenting with some powder found in a bottle, Ford Anderson ap- i plied a lighted match and the con tents of the bottle exploded, burning him on the face and one arm, severely, Saturday morning. He was taken to Dr. Bowman, who dressed the wounds. He is getting along nicely although the burns are very painful. . Moving to Cameron. Mr. and Mrs. S. D. Juleson have moved here from Ottawa, Kas., and will occupy the J. W. Perry property on West Fifth street. Mr. Juleson is a traveling man. Delivered Memorial Address. Rev. John Boone drove to Plymouth, Carroll county, Sunday afternoon, where he delivered the annual memorial address for the I. O. O. F. lodge there. Kidder Lady Dies. Mrs. T. J. Anient died at her home in Kidder Tuesday night after a long illness from cancer. Funeral services are being held this afternoon. EW STYLE GLASSES Shown May 26th. Those greasy, corroded, or old style glasses make you look ten years older and brand you as out-of-date, even more than old hats or clothing. Let. Dr. Palm show you the newest frames at Midland ho tel in Cameron next Monday; $3.00 to ?3.00. Adv. (13-lt) Jas. C. Baker A Bishop New Member of Episcopacy Is Son of Former President of Missouri Wesleyan College. Methodists of the world in their general conference at Kansas City yesterday elected as a bishop Dr. James C. Baker, son of the late Dr. B. W. Daker, years ago president of Missouri Wesleyan college in Cameron. He was at that time a student at the college. His preferment will be learn ed of with genuine satisfaction by old friends in this city and throughout the Missouri conference. Dr. Baker was the founder of the Wesley Foundation movement which was established at the University of Illinois to provide religious influence for students in tax supported institutions and is still in charge there. The movement has spread throughout the nation. Five years ago, Dr. Baker was one of the speakers In connection with the installing of Dr. E. F. Buck as president of Missouri Wesleyan college. ALUM XI HOLD BANQUET Joy and sorrow co-mingled Tuesday evening when alumni of Missouri Wesleyan surrounded the banquet tables in Rice Hall for the annual banquet.Happy meeting of graduates of former years was the occasion for happy reminiscences, but the merry company paused in its enjoyment and sadness swept through all hearts as tributes were paid to the memories of Dean H. C. Kelsey and Dr. E. B. Thompson, prominent alumni, who during the past few months had passed suddenly out of this life. President Lester C. Slayton presided, and extended greetings from the alumni to the present graduates. Clarence Byers, class president, responded on behalf of the class. The invocation was by Rev. Jos. W. Thompson of Bethany. President Gale and Dr. L. A. Wilson responded to toasts on the present and future of Wesleyan, and Dr. Stella Dodd of Sononchia, C. P., India, spoke on "A Wesleyanite in India." The charge to the graduating class was given by Prof. Wilson Thomas. Music was furnished by two quartets, one of women and the other of men the singers being Mesdames Lou Gene Evans Woods, Mildred Robison Belcher, Marion Hulsizer Williams and Gladys Frances Hicks; and Messrs. Luther Swift, Charles Groom, Joe Williams and Kenneth Crawford. The attendance and interest were excellent. R. T. Z'S INITIATED Ten new members were iniiiated into the R. T. Z. society, Friday morn ing. The R. T. Z. is a high school society and ten new members are chosen each year. The new members were taken to the Park school where breakfast was cooked. They were then dressed in old-fashioned clothing and taKen to the college chapel. After chapel services, a parade was formed and traversed up and down Third street. Saturday night they were the guests at a line party at the Royal. The new members: Misses Mildred Brown, Ailene Brower, Louise De-Shon, Dorothy Crawford, Virginia Holland, Guenavere Knoch, Mae Morton, Esther Shaw, Elizabeth Whiteaker and Frances Watson. ALPHA PSI OMEGA The Theta cast from Missouri Wes leyan College of the Alpha Psi Ome ga, a national honorary dramatic fra ternity, held a 6 o'clock dinner last evening at the Park Cafe. This has become an annual affair and is eagerly looked forward to by all members of the Grand Cast. The dinner followed the initiation of three Wesleyan students into fellowship of this fraternity: Eileen Kranz, Page Pendleton and Bert Rushton. CHIEF ENGINEER HIS FRIEND Prof. Louis Theilmann was greatly pleased when President Coolidge named Carl W. Sturtevant of New York City as chief engineer for flood control work in the Mississippi val ley. In the first place, Sturtevant is am ply qualified, and in the second he and Prof. Theilmann were classmates in their college days. WiU Leave for Europe. Mrs. G. G. Brown has received word from her son Sidney, in St. Louis that he will leave there Monday from New York, where he will board the ship Maria, for Italy. Sidney will help look after a load of mules which is being shipped from Missouri to Europe. He expects to be gone from six to eight weeks and is anticipating a wonderful trip sight-seeing. Will Teach in Hawaii. William O'Neal, who has been teaching the past winter in Winona, Minn., returned to Cameron Saturday for the summer vacation. Mr. O'Neal was offered the principalship of the Win ona schools for next school term, but did not accept, and will teach in the schools at Honokaa, Hawaii. He will leave for the islands in August. Passed Away. Mrs. Caroline Bell (colored), aged 75, passed away at her home on West Cornhill Tuesday evening after an illness of one day. Mrs. Bell suffered a stroke of paralysis Tuesday morning and died that evening. Driving New Ford. W. C. Sampson is the owner of a new Tudor Ford purchased from Walter W. Hammer, Cameron dealer, delivered Friday. Death As Result Of Fall Ulnier Warner, Roofing Expert, Step-Ieil ltackward fo Death From Goodrich Auditorium Roof. High winds recently whipped part of the roofing off the Goodrich auditorium and the P. Stauffer Rooiing Co. of Mobeiiy, who laid the roof sent, sent a force of workmen here to repair the damage. Wulklng about on the roof superintending the job, Saturday, Elsworth Warner, 47 years old, who was in charge of the work as an expert, stepped backward from the roof. In the fall, he sustained a compound fracture of one leg and a broken arm besides internal injuries. lie was rushed to the Methodist hospital in the Poland ambulance by Dr. L. A. Wilson, who was called to attend him, but his injuries were so severe that death ensued Sunday. WILLI A MS- HEN I) F. R SO N Miss Grace Henderson and Roland Williams were united in marriage Monday afternoon at the home of Rev. H. R. Mills, pastor of the First M. E. church in St. Joseph. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Henderson, for many years prominent citizens of Cameron. She is a graduate of Missouri Wes leyan college of Cameron and the Curry School of Expression at Boston, and has taught expression at the Missouri Christian college in Camden Point, at William Woods college at Fulton and at Missouri Wesleyan col lege, bhe is a young woman of un usual talent and charm and is highly popular possessing a wide circle of friends. The groom is also a member of one of the community's old and esteemed families, being a large land owner and farmer south of Cameron. The happy couple will reside on his farm south of town. The Sun joins their many friends in wishing them a long, prosperous and happy wedded life. M. W. C. RECITAL A splendid recital was given at the College chapel Monday evening by Miss Ruth Pittman, reader; Miss Vera Lou Saxer, pianist, and Miss Eleanor Downey, pianist. A large crowd was present to enjoy the delightful pro gram, which was as follows: Readings, "Rainbow Land" and "Rejected," Miss Pittman, accompanied by Miss Saxer; piano solos, "Arabesque en forme d' Etude," and "The Old Refrain," Miss Saxer; reading, "Molly's Boy," Miss Pittman; piano duets, "Butterfly," "Eastern Intermezzo" and "Gypsy Dance," Misses Downey and Saxer; readings, "Black Blue Grass Widow," and "Imph-m," Miss Pittman; piano solo, "Romance," Vera Lou Saxer; readings, "L'Envoi" and "Mu.4ic on the Rappahauock,," Miss Pittman, accompanied by Miss Downey, vocalist, and Miss Saxer, pianist.Ushers: Misses Irene Moon, Lorraine Shirts, Ada Ruth Alley, Lois Dusenberry, Gertrude Buck and Thel-ma Farris. CITY COUNCIL MEETS The city council met in regular session Monday evening with Mayor J. C. McComb, presiding. The minutes were read and the usual appropriation ordinance passed. The city attorney was directed to prepare an ordinance prohibiting bill boards in the city limits. The meeting adjourned until Friday night "when bids will be received for the graveling of Orange and Prospect streets. TRI BETA BANQUET The Beta Beta Beta Biological fra ternity of Missouri Wesleyan college enjoyed a banquet at the Park Cafe Monday evening. The honor guests were the faculty advisors, Dr. L. A. Wilson and Prof. L. G. Slayton, and the Mesdames Slayton and Wilson. Goldie Boureltn v.: toast master. The idea of the three B's was carried out in the toasts. Prof. Slayton gave a toast on "Biology," David Foster on "Botany," and Dr. Wilson, "Bacteriology." A saxophone solo was given by Cleo Hardin and Miss Hazel Porter gave a vocal solo. This was the closing event of the Beta Beta Beta fraternity for the year. (13-lt) T,,K ( 0I Lf:(;K baccalaureate Inspiring Sermon by President Flem. ing of linker UnUersity Heard By Many. An audience which taxed the capacity of Khe . spacious Methodist church attended the annual baccalaureate services for Missouri Wesleyan college Sunday morning. Services at other churches were dismissed for the morning hour and the various congregations united in the exercises. In the processional were the faculty, the graduates and the members of the large chorus choir. In accordance with the custom established throughout many years, the Hallelujah Chorus was rendered by the choir, and was beautifully given. The choir was directed by Hadley Crawford, a student under the late Prof. H. C. Kelsey. President E. J. Gale of Missouri Wesleyan introduced as the speaker, President W. B. Fleming of Baker University. The coming of Dr. Fleming, at the invitation of President Gale and the Senior class, was highly fitting as a merger Is in process between the two institutions and while Missouri Wesleyan will continue to do two years of work here, it will be a part of Baker University, and by the merger, Baker University becomes a part of this community as well as carrying from this time forward the work of the upper two years heretofore at Missouri Wesleyan. Dr. Fleming's sermon was an urge to the discovery of worth while things and his thought was developed with a clearness and eloquence that impressed it upon the hearts and minds of his hearers. So many things we desire are within reach if we but knew how to put forth our hand and take them, Dr. Fleming told the class and his audience. But all too often people hurry here and there in quest for their heart's desire and never find it because they fail to envision the things worthwhile. Supreme among all objects sought by man is the finding of God, Dr. Fleming said. Many miss Him, "Though he be not far from any one of us." To miss God is to miss the supreme good in life; the very essence of life itself. Getting education is desirable; achieving success in professional or business life is desirable, but the finding of God in the heart of an individual ennobles his life", broadens and sweetens it as nothing else can do. Prefacing his sermon, Dr. Fleming took occasion to express cordial feelings for Missouri AVesleyan college and its interests, and toward this community. It is his belief that the new relationship will prove of lasting benefit both to the interests of Missouri Wesleyan college and Baker University, and in the largest degree to the cause of christian education. Dr. Fleming's earnestness, his devotion to the highest and best education for young people and his spirit of friendliness made a most favorable inipressio;i on his many hearers. ANNUAL ARTS CONTEST The annual fine arts contest under direction of the M. W. C. Alumni Association, was held at the college chapel Tuesday evening. The program was presided over by Prof. Lester Slayton, alumni president. A large crowd was present and enjoyed the splendid program. Winners in the contests were as follows: Piano, first Vera Lou Saxer, who played "Romance"; second, Mildred Kelsey, "Prelude in G Minor," and third, Frances Warren, "Jugglery." HOUSE FOR RENT Small cottage, well located, closa in on paved street; heat, water, electric lights, bathroom and garage. Fine neighborhood. Inquire at The Sun cf- Jfice or phone 707. (10-tf)
Every year in the United States alone,2,077,000 couples make a legal and spiritual decision to spend the rest of their lives together ...
(Laughter) and not to have sex with anyone else, ever. He buys a ring, she buys a dress. They go shopping for all sorts of things. She takes him to Arthur Murray for ballroom dancing lessons. And the big day comes. And they'll stand before God and family and some guy her dad once did business with, and they'll vow that nothing, not abject poverty, not life-threatening illness, not complete and utter misery will ever put the tiniest damper on their eternal love and devotion. (Laughter)
These optimistic young bastards promise to honor and cherish each other through hot flashes and mid-life crises and a cumulative 50-lb. weight gain, until that far-off day when one of them is finally able to rest in peace. You know, because they can't hear the snoring anymore. And then they'll get stupid drunk and smash cake in each others' faces and do the "Macarena," and we'll be there showering them with towels and toasters and drinking their free booze and throwing birdseed at them every single time -- even though we know, statistically, half of them will be divorced within a decade.
Of course, the other half won't , right? They'll keep forgetting anniversaries and arguing about where to spend holidays and debating which way the toilet paper should come off of the roll. And some of them will even still be enjoying each others' company when neither of them can chew solid food anymore.
And researchers want to know why. I mean, look, it doesn't take a double-blind, placebo-controlled study to figure out what makes a marriage not work. Disrespect, boredom, too much time on Facebook, having sex with other people. But you can have the exact opposite of all of those things -- respect, excitement, a broken Internet connection, mind-numbing monogamy -- and the thing still can go to hell in a hand basket. So what's going on when it doesn't? What do the folks who make it all the way to side-by-side burial plots have in common? What are they doing right? What can we learn from them? And if you're still happily sleeping solo, why should you stop what you're doing and make it your life's work to find that one special person that you can annoy for the rest of your life?
Well researchers spend billions of your tax dollars trying to figure that out. They stalk blissful couples and they study their every move and mannerism. And they try to pinpoint what it is that sets them apart from their miserable neighbors and friends. And it turns out, the success stories share a few similarities, actually, beyond they don't have sex with other people.
For instance, in the happiest marriages, the wife is thinner and better looking than the husband. (Laughter) Obvious, right. It's obvious that this leads to marital bliss because, women, we care a great deal about being thin and good looking, whereas men mostly care about sex ... ideally with women who are thinner and better looking than they are. The beauty of this research though is that no one is suggesting that women have to be thin to be happy; we just have to be thinner than our partners. So instead of all that laborious dieting and exercising, we just need to wait for them to get fat, maybe bake a few pies. This is good information to have, and it's not that complicated.
Research also suggests that the happiest couples are the ones that focus on the positives. For example, the happy wife. Instead of pointing out her husband's growing gut or suggesting he go for a run, she might say, "Wow, honey, thank you for going out of your way to make me relatively thinner." These are couples who can find good in any situation. "Yeah, it was devastating when we lost everything in that fire, but it's kind of nice sleeping out here under the stars, and it's a good thing you've got all that body fat to keep us warm."
One of my favorite studies found that the more willing a husband is to do house work, the more attractive his wife will find him. Because we needed a study to tell us this. But here's what's going on here. The more attractive she finds him, the more sex they have; the more sex they have, the nicer he is to her; the nicer he is to her, the less she nags him about leaving wet towels on the bed -- and ultimately, they live happily ever after. In other words, men, you might want to pick it up a notch in the domestic department.
Here's an interesting one. One study found that people who smile in childhood photographs are less likely to get a divorce. This is an actual study, and let me clarify. The researchers were not looking at documented self-reports of childhood happiness or even studying old journals. The data were based entirely on whether people looked happy in these early pictures. Now I don't know how old all of you are, but when I was a kid, your parents took pictures with a special kind of camera that held something called film, and, by God, film was expensive. They didn't take 300 shots of you in that rapid-fire digital video mode and then pick out the nicest, smileyest one for the Christmas card. Oh no. They dressed you up, they lined you up, and you smiled for the fucking camera like they told you to or you could kiss your birthday party goodbye. But still, I have a huge pile of fake happy childhood pictures and I'm glad they make me less likely than some people to get a divorce.
So what else can you do to safeguard your marriage? Do not win an Oscar for best actress. (Laughter) I'm serious. Bettie Davis, Joan Crawford, Hallie Berry, Hillary Swank, Sandra Bullock, Reese Witherspoon, all of them single soon after taking home that statue. They actually call it the Oscar curse. It is the marriage kiss of death and something that should be avoided.
And it's not just successfully starring in films that's dangerous. It turns out, merely watching a romantic comedy causes relationship satisfaction to plummet. (Laughter) Apparently, the bitter realization that maybe it could happen to us, but it obviously hasn't and it probably never will, makes our lives seem unbearably grim in comparison. And theoretically, I suppose if we opt for a film where someone gets brutally murdered or dies in a fiery car crash, we are more likely to walk out of that theater feeling like we've got it pretty good.
Drinking alcohol, it seems, is bad for your marriage. Yeah. I can't tell you anymore about that one because I stopped reading it at the headline. But here's a scary one: Divorce is contagious. That's right -- when you have a close couple friend split up, it increases your chances of getting a divorce by 75 percent. Now I have to say, I don't get this one at all. My husband and I have watched quite a few friends divide their assets and then struggle with being our age and single in an age of sexting and Viagra and eHarmony. And I'm thinking they've done more for my marriage than a lifetime of therapy ever could.
So now you may be wondering, why does anyone get married ever? Well the U.S. federal government counts more than a thousand legal benefits to being someone's spouse -- a list that includes visitation rights in jail, but hopefully you'll never need that one. But beyond the profound federal perks, married people make more money. We're healthier, physically and emotionally. We produce happier, more stable and more successful kids. We have more sex than our supposedly swinging single friends -- believe it or not. We even live longer, which is a pretty compelling argument for marrying someone you like a lot in the first place.
Now if you're not currently experiencing the joy of the joint tax return, I can't tell you how to find a chore-loving person of the approximately ideal size and attractiveness who prefers horror movies and doesn't have a lot of friends hovering on the brink of divorce, but I can only encourage you to try, because the benefits, as I've pointed out, are significant. The bottom line is, whether you're in it or you're searching for it, I believe marriage is an institution worth pursuing and protecting. So I hope you'll use the information I've given you today to weigh your personal strengths against your own risk factors.
For instance, in my marriage, I'd say I'm doing okay. One the one hand, I have a husband who's annoyingly lean and incredibly handsome. So I'm obviously going to need fatten him up. And like I said, we have those divorced friends who may secretly or subconsciously be trying to break us up. So we have to keep an eye on that. And we do like a cocktail or two. On the other hand, I have the fake happy picture thing. And also, my husband does a lot around the house, and would happily never see another romantic comedy as long as he lives.
So I've got all those things going for me. But just in case, I plan to work extra hard to not win an Oscar anytime soon. And for the good of your relationships, I would encourage you to do the same. I'll see you at the bar.

And they'll stand before God/ and family/ and some guy her dad once did business with,/ and they'll vow that nothing,/ not abject poverty, not life-threatening illness, not complete and utter misery will ever put the tiniest damper/ on their eternal love and devotion.//

They'll keep forgetting/ anniversaries/ and arguing about where to spend holidays/ and debating/ which way/ the toilet paper should come off/ of the roll.//
And some of them will even still be enjoying each others/' company/ when neither of them can chew solid food anymore.//

Situation: A CEO is concerned that there is insufficient fairness and accountability within her company. One manager is paid hourly and the CEO is thinking about shifting this person to salary plus bonus both to put them on par with other mangers and to create more accountability. How do you create accountability?
What exactly are you trying to achieve? An operations manager is paid competitively at hourly rates, even compared to salaried employees. The issue is that this person has no responsibility for results as they relate to the P&L. Given this, the group consensus is that it is better to have this person on an incentive program that ties compensation to the performance results that you want.
One objective is that you want this employee to contribute more to planning, strategy or the company‚Äôs attempts to develop solutions to the challenges that they face. Have you spoken to the employee about your expectations? Does the employee realize that you want or value their input? Direct communication with the employee is important.
While the employee understands his responsibilities in the operations area, be sure that he is aware that he is also important to the profitability of the company, and managing operational expenses which are contributors to that profitability. Depending upon the individual‚Äôs background, he may need training about the links between expenses and the P&L.
Adjust the employee‚Äôs compensation by switching from hourly to salary. Make the base livable, but not comfortable, and tie the bonus (which will make the total compensation package comfortable) to the profitability of the business. This will have an immediate effect.
Clearly explain to the employee that you value his creativity and input. Give this person the freedom to contribute and make it clear that his contribution is expected. Early on encourage this and acknowledge contributions in meetings.
This entry was posted in Leadership, Manufacturing & Operations, Team and tagged Communication, Employee, Expectations, Expense, Fairness, Hourly, Management, Objective, P&L, Pay, Planning, Salary, Training on November 12, 2017 by Sandy.
Situation: A company has a significant monthly payroll, and business is growing. Accounts payable collections are 90-120 days. Their challenge is to finance the gap. They have tried, but can‚Äôt get their bank to provide financing. An SBA loan will help. How do you manage cash flow gaps?
Non-bank financing offers better rates than banks, with access to cash from the lender on reasonable notice.
Investigate Lendingclub.com. They offer business loans up to $300K at 5.9%. Lendingclub.com operates by spreading the risk over thousands of investors.
Talk to lots of banks ‚Äì not just those with whom who‚Äôve worked in the past. Given your cash flow needs and good credit history, if you offer to shift all of your business to another bank you may get a more positive response. Once you have talked to other banks, let your current bank know your plans. They may become more responsive.
Change your service policy so that you give your best service to customers who pay you fastest. Once the purchasers at companies with whom you work learn about this, they will pressure their AP people to speed their payments to you.
Offer customers early pay discounts ‚Äì 1% net 10 or ¬Ω of the Lendingclub.com rate to your biggest clients.
Befriend lower level employees in client companies. Particularly those with whom you have regular business contact.
Key Words: Payroll, Financing, Accounts, Payable, Bank, Lendingclub, Non-Bank, Service, ACH, Payment, Early, Pay, Discount
This entry was posted in Finance, Manufacturing & Operations and tagged Accounts, ACH, Bank, Discount, Early, Financing, Lendingclub, Non-Bank, Pay, Payable, Payment, Payroll, Service on October 16, 2016 by Sandy.
Situation: A company‚Äôs staff is highly paid. Historically, annual raises have been 4-5%; however some individuals are above industry salary ranges. The CEO doesn‚Äôt want to lose key individuals who would be expensive to replace. The company is planning salary increases for the end of this year. If the level is lower than historic averages they are concerned about the impact. Are planning for salary increases this year? How will you communicate your decision to employees?
What‚Äôs the problem? Even in an improving economy your employees are lucky to be making what they do! On top of this, you need to consider profitability compared to last year as well as historic levels. Selectively share financial data with your employees as well as financial realities ‚Äì your and their top priority are to keep the company healthy.
Gather data on salary ranges for roles in your industry. Good sources are Salary.com for national data (it may be dated) or Assets Unlimited‚Äôs Silicon Valley Survey for up-to-date salary information by industry and position. This will help you to prepare for conversations with employees who are currently paid above the range for their positions.
If you have employees above the range and do not want to give them raises, give them bonuses or spot bonuses for work well done.
Formalize your bonus system ‚Äì base bonuses on performance metrics. Consider tying bonuses to net margin performance for the company or for departments that can impact new margin.
This entry was posted in Finance, Team and tagged Bonus, Communicate, Data, Historic, Impact, Level, Metrics, Pay, Performance, Positive on October 25, 2015 by Sandy.
Situation: A family-owned business has a family member on hourly pay who puts in excessive overtime. The cost of overtime significantly cuts into company profits. The CEO wants to cut back these overtime hours and get the employee to work more efficiently. At the same time, she feels that maintaining peace within the extended family is important. How do you cut excessive overtime for a single employee?
Situations like this within a family business are delicate because of relationships beyond the work place. Treat this individual respectfully, but make it clear that you have to act in the best interests of the company and all employees.
Communicate to the employee: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to take advantage of you by requiring this much overtime.‚Äù
Let the individual know that you are looking for additional talent and want to more tightly define the roles.
Develop a company policy on overtime that limits the amount of overtime that any one individual can accrue. If anyone starts to approach this limit, then have a process in place that shifts additional overtime to others.
This is a serious problem for the company. It calls for company transformation. Enlist the employee as a champion for the cause of transforming the company. Keep this a positive vision.
If the individual is not a keeper: start controlling hours, but don‚Äôt give a raise. Let them leave on their own time.
This entry was posted in Finance, Manufacturing & Operations, Team and tagged Business, Description, Family, Hour, Job, Limit, Pay, Policy, Relationship on May 24, 2015 by Sandy.
Situation: A company pays employees based on skill level. Raises are given as an employee learns additional skills. In some cases, when they give an employee a raise, productivity drops. The company has tried other approaches including bonus systems and profit sharing but did not find these effective. How do you effectively motivate hourly employees?
Before trying a new motivation scheme, find out what matters to your employees. It may not be either bonuses or profit sharing.
Develop and send out a questionnaire listing different factors ‚Äì revenue sharing, bonuses, creativity, doing quality work ‚Äì ask what matters to you? Get their feedback.
People work for respect ‚Äì many studies have shown that as long as the payment offered is fair, salary is secondary.
Hire an advocate for your employees ‚Äì a part-time HR person. An important role for this individual will be to determine what motivates employees, what they want from their jobs, and how improvements in both processes and the working environment can boost productivity.
At companies that use the Toyota Production System employees receive points for process improvements. At the end of the year they receive a cash payout based on the points earned during the year.
Employees are rewarded publicly. The incentives are cash, recognition and respect. These companies find that recognition and respect trumps cash.
Depending upon your cost structure, it may be more productive to focus on scrap reduction. Bring in someone with experience who can find the sources of scrap. The effort will pay for itself rapidly.
During the hiring process, require educational attainment as evidence of the individual‚Äôs commitment.
Look for skills experience ‚Äì machinist, etc. Match skills and experience to your needs. This will lead to faster learning curves and will help to reduce waste.
This entry was posted in Manufacturing & Operations, Strategy, Team and tagged Criteria, Employee, Environment, Feedback, Hiring, Motivate, Pay, Process, Productivity, Raises, Skill, Waste, Work on March 2, 2014 by Sandy.
Situation: A company has hired interns in the past and wants to upgrade their intern program to attract more interns from top schools. How do you attract interns from top schools?
Top schools want to build lasting relationships with the companies to whom they send interns. In addition, the ability of top schools to attract top students increasingly relies on the placement rate of the school, so this can be a win-win proposition for both company and school. Take the time to cultivate this relationship and let the school‚Äôs representatives know your intentions. Get to know the top professors in programs from which you wish to recruit interns.
Provide a high quality internship experience. Treat interns as though they were normal employees during internships. Give them a job, objectives and tell them that you will evaluate you as though they were FTEs. They will feel more like members of the team and will have a higher quality internship experience. They will likely tell their placement office and other students about their experience. Interns should understand that if all goes well, the company MAY have a job for them; no job is guaranteed.
If you want more applicants from top schools then view your internship program as an investment. Look at it as a recruiting tool, not as an expense.
Pay for interns may not be same as FTEs ‚Äì frequently interns are paid less, and don‚Äôt get the same benefits as FTEs. Before you make an offer or hire, call the school from which the potential intern comes and check out the candidate‚Äôs representations as to expected salary, etc.
The CEO of a technology company has hired many engineer interns. Many of these were subsequently hired as employees. Overall their success has been good, but not fantastic. Similar to a new employee, it takes time for an intern to get up to speed.
This entry was posted in Strategy, Team and tagged Evaluation, Intern, Investment, Pay, Performance, Recruit, Relationship, School, Success, Top, Treatment on January 26, 2014 by Sandy.
Situation: A company is about to launch a Beta version of their web-based software. The CEO strives for perfection. What is sufficient for launch, and can the company tolerate imperfections in Beta version? When is ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù enough?
Many successful software companies ‚Äì think Microsoft ‚Äì have realized that finishing the last 10-20% of a new release can be as expensive and time consuming as the first 80-90%. The challenges are often greater and it‚Äôs difficult to prioritize the final pieces. So they release when the software is 80-90% complete, prioritize the final pieces based on user feedback, and focus on quick response to user feedback.
You really have no idea how users will experience a new web-based program until you hear it from them. They will tell you what does and does not need to be fixed. They may even be able to help you fix it! Craig‚Äôs list stinks from a pure GUI perspective, but is highly popular and successful.
Get the Beta program out ASAP. What you perceive as imperfections may not appear as problems to young Beta users, and may in a way add a quirky appeal to the user experience.
Find a customer or group of customers who will pay for the program. Only this proves its actual worth. There can be conditions for a Beta release and discounts, but if nobody is willing to pay, where is the value?
Consider releasing your Beta version in a college campus environment and invite both participation and feedback. College students are very web-savvy, more tolerant of Beta programs, and crave the opportunity to contribute.
As an additional bonus, when you are ready to launch, college students are great at helping you generate buzz and early adoption because they talk to so many of their friends from both college and high school.
This entry was posted in Sales & Marketing, Service and tagged Beta, College, Customer, Experience, Feedback, Good, Launch, Pay, Perfect, Software, User, Value on July 21, 2013 by Sandy.
Situation: A company is the leader in an expanding market. To sustain growth, they must transform how their people operate so that they better address and serve the needs of their target customers. How do you transform company culture?
We have a saying at Eloqua: Culture eats strategy for breakfast. More important than this year‚Äôs product strategy is the culture you build that let‚Äôs employees make decisions on the fly because they know ‚Äúthat‚Äôs how we do things at Eloqua.‚Äù
Look at how you pay and reward your people. We all receive bonuses on the same team metrics: company sales, profitability, and customer satisfaction. If the team wins, we all win.
We are not a democracy, but everyone has a voice. Although we make decisions as a business, we avoid top-down management. We push as much authority and accountability as far down the organization chart as we can. You can only do this well with a strong culture.
We adopted a mantra to guide our way, ‚ÄúGet it done ‚Äì Do it right‚Äù, and a set of metrics to make it part of our culture.
We created a two-by-two grid, with ‚ÄúGet it Done‚Äù on the Y-axis and ‚ÄúDo it Right‚Äù on the X-axis on which all employees, including the Executive Team, are plotted. If rated in the top right quadrant, that employee is doing well. If someone finds himself or herself plotted in the Upper Left quadrant (getting it done, but not doing it right), that person has one quarter to improve. Lower Right people get two months. Lower lefters are out that day.
We can measure ‚Äúgetting it done‚Äù using standard quantitative metrics, but ‚Äúdoing it right‚Äù is more qualitative. We ask questions like, ‚ÄúIs the person a positive source of energy for the team? Does she go above and beyond for other staff and for customers?‚Äù We provide examples to help evaluators plot individual performance.
Once we instituted this matrix, one of our top selling sales reps was evaluated as being in the top left quadrant. When he only paid lip-service to changing and didn‚Äôt correct this behavior after a quarter, we let him go, numbers and all. This decision was both a major ‚Äúwow‚Äù and a major win for the company.
This entry was posted in Leadership and tagged Culture, Customer, Growth, Needs, Pay, Reward, Transform on December 22, 2011 by Sandy.
